etymologies: mid 17th century (first recorded in the Greek sense): from Greek, literally ‘depth’. The current sense was introduced by Alexander Pope in the early 18th century

definitions: (especially in a work of literature) an effect of anticlimax created by an unintentional lapse in mood from the sublime to the trivial or ridiculous

examples.text: his epic poem has passages of almost embarrassing bathos
a nice balance between the colloquial, which might have led to bathos, and an over-polished style

shortDefinitions: effect of anticlimax created by unintentional lapse in mood from sublime to trivial or ridiculous
